Author: Bowers, Alex J.
Title: Analyzing the Longitudinal K-12 Grading Histories of Entire Cohorts of Students: Grades, Data Driven Decision Making, Dropping out and Hierarchical Cluster Analysis
Abstract Note: School personnel currently lack an effective method to pattern and visually interpret disaggregated achievement data collected on students as a means to help inform decision making. This study, through the examination of longitudinal K-12 teacher assigned grading histories for entire cohorts of students from a school district (n=188), demonstrates a novel application of hierarchical cluster analysis and pattern visualization in which all data points collected on every student in a cohort can be patterned, visualized and interpreted to aid in data driven decision making by teachers and administrators. Additionally, as a proof-of-concept study, overall schooling outcomes, such as student dropout or taking a college entrance exam, are identified from the data patterns and compared to past methods of dropout identification as one example of the usefulness of the method. Hierarchical cluster analysis correctly identified over 80% of the students who dropped out using the entire student grade history patterns from either K-12 or K-8. (Contains 5 figures.)
Short Title: Analyzing the Longitudinal K-12 Grading Histories of Entire Cohorts of Students
Notes:
This paper examines data driven decision making by using hierarchical cluster analysis (HCA) with a heatmap on the grade history of k12 students to predict dropouts. The outcome of the study, though similar when compare to a regression analysis in predicting student dropouts, differs in the successful demonstration of individual data through clustering rather than an aggregation of the entire data set.

The use of heat map with clustering is rather inspiring since they together facilitates the visualization and comparison of assigned grades for subjects and subgroups. It maybe interesting to apply clustering, heat map and the idea of mixing for educational resource distribution across a country.
Automatic Tags: data; data analysis; Decision Making; Dropouts; Elementary School Students; Grades (Scholastic); Identification; MULTIVARIATE analysis; School Districts; Secondary School Students

Author: Grunspan, Daniel Z.; Wiggins, Benjamin L.; Goodreau, Steven M.
Title: Understanding Classrooms through Social Network Analysis: A Primer for Social Network Analysis in Education Research
Abstract Note: Social interactions between students are a major and underexplored part of undergraduate education. Understanding how learning relationships form in undergraduate classrooms, as well as the impacts these relationships have on learning outcomes, can inform educators in unique ways and improve educational reform. Social network analysis (SNA) provides the necessary tool kit for investigating questions involving relational data. We introduce basic concepts in SNA, along with methods for data collection, data processing, and data analysis, using a previously collected example study on an undergraduate biology classroom as a tutorial. We conduct descriptive analyses of the structure of the network of costudying relationships. We explore generative processes that create observed study networks between students and also test for an association between network position and success on exams. We also cover practical issues, such as the unique aspects of human subjects review for network studies. Our aims are to convince readers that using SNA in classroom environments allows rich and informative analyses to take place and to provide some initial tools for doing so, in the process inspiring future educational studies incorporating relational data.
Short Title: Understanding Classrooms through Social Network Analysis
Notes:
• Analyze students’ social interactions in the context of classrooms to see how that relationship impacts their study – individual and community level over time (relational data and Social Network Analysis).
  • Basic concepts in SNA
    • How relationships form and these relationships’ impact on actors, also called nodes (individuals, organizations, websites). A group of actors make up a network.
    • Network types:

1)          unipartite (author to author, student to student – only one type of actor), bipartite (author to paper, student to classes – actors with the groups they belong)

2)          undirected: ties between actors are bidirectional / directed: associated direction, one think this of the other, but they other does not necessarily think one in the same way.

3)          Binary ties: examine a relation’s existence/ valued ties: consider quantitative information about a relation

  • Data collection

1)          Time frame (static, implicitly dynamic, explicitly dynamic- multiple and continuous data collection)

2)          Sample selection: ego-centric (examine individuals and their local social atmosphere, easier in terms of data collection, ethnics, and subjects view)/ census networks, or whole networks (large population of actors, also examine network structures) challenges of census networks: hard to collect data, need to find a population, miss connection that is not included in the population of interests (student to teaching assistant, when the relationship being examined is student to student), withdraw and adding in variables, nonresponse.

3)          How many ties are present and who is connected with whom (homophily – social selection, or work together because of same attributes and social influence, or one is influenced and changed by another in terms of attributes because they work together) *What if the connection is mixture of both?

4)          Dyad-level analysis VS Triads (transitive triad – hierarchy, one giving and one receiving & cyclical triad – egalitarianism, everyone giving and receiving)

5)          Centrality: Degree centrality (total number of connections), Betweenness centrality (role of bridges between two actors, airport example), Closeness centrality (how close one actor is to the other),  Eigenvector centrality (being connected to other well-connected individuals)

  • Methods and Concerns for Data Collection

1)          Avoid overuse of survey: collect background information from instructor and institution

2)          Closed-ended format: limit error, easier to process, but can lead to name confusions. Make sure the choices are varied and comprehensive.

3)          Timing: earliest possible to avoid forgetting, class withdrawal, etc. /regular intervals or around important events.

4)          IRB and consent: problem of authority, anonymous and identifiers removal.

Author: Young, Jeffrey R.
Title: Why Students Should Own Their Educational Data
Publication Title: The Chronicle of Higher Education Blogs: Wired Campus
Notes:
• I found Mr. Rose’ example of the cockpit inspiring. When I looked through the comments below, I saw some readers responded to the text by stating that the idea would be fall apart with a large student body. However, I wanted to say the idea of “customization” is not news, we have been seeing fashion merchandise allow people to design their own types of shoes on the website. Of course, one’s learning process could be much more complex than designing a shoe, but I think it is still doable if we divide the process into manageable small pieces.
  • I think it is a fantastic idea to not force students into the mode of average, but give them a chance to learn and grow within a broader range that only indicates the highest point and the lowest one, so they have enough room to change and develop. Then the question comes what are the edges in a classroom if we were to “ban the average” and “design to edges?” 
  • How do we find the adjustable seat in a learning classroom? Mr. Rose’s solution is to use technology to customize teaching materials. I also heard about differentiated instruction that focused on pedagogical strategy.
  • I agreed with Mr. Rose that we do not have enough data in the past to analyze and respond to individual’s needs. It will be unrealistic to think that teachers will go through each student profile to understand their interests, conduct face-to-face interview with them to learn about their past experiences, hold a parent conference to learn about their home environment.  But now with technology, we can collect, store, and analyze data about students in a way we could never think of before.
  • The interview touched on ideas such as the difference between MOOC and traditional classroom, and the transparency and ownership of data, I would like it to expand more on these two topics though since I feel it is not thoroughly explained.

Author: Corbett, Albert T.; Anderson, John R.
Title: Knowledge tracing: Modeling the acquisition of procedural knowledge
Abstract Note: This paper describes an effort to model students' changing knowledge state during skill acquisition. Students in this research are learning to write short programs with the ACT Programming Tutor (APT). APT is constructed around a production rule cognitive model of programming knowledge, called theideal student model. This model allows the tutor to solve exercises along with the student and provide assistance as necessary. As the student works, the tutor also maintains an estimate of the probability that the student has learned each of the rules in the ideal model, in a process calledknowledge tracing. The tutor presents an individualized sequence of exercises to the student based on these probability estimates until the student has ‘mastered’ each rule. The programming tutor, cognitive model and learning and performance assumptions are described. A series of studies is reviewed that examine the empirical validity of knowledge tracing and has led to modifications in the process. Currently the model is quite successful in predicting test performance. Further modifications in the modeling process are discussed that may improve performance levels.
Notes:
The paper manages to make progress and not settle with the initial knowledge tracing model based on probability but rather validates the study with experiments and successive modifications that help to address the individuality of rules and students.

It is interesting to see the test performance evaluation be broken down into two factors, knowledge of the rules and performance parameters. Within the performance parameters, the slip factor determines how well the students can apply the mastery of the knowledge. In other words, knowledge of the rules does not guarantee the application of them. The slip factor is worth further analysis to take into account students' other skills and characteristics that are difficult to measure during the exam, such as time management, flexibility, and ability to work under pressure.
Automatic Tags: Education (general); empirical validity; individual differences; intelligent tutoring systems; Learning; Management of Computing and Information Systems; mastery learning; Multimedia Information Systems; procedural knowledge; Psychology, general; student modeling; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction

Author: Siemens, George; Baker, Ryan S. J. d.
Title: Learning Analytics and Educational Data Mining: Towards Communication and Collaboration
Publication Title: Proceedings of the 2Nd International Conference on Learning Analytics and Knowledge
Abstract Note: Growing interest in data and analytics in education, teaching, and learning raises the priority for increased, high-quality research into the models, methods, technologies, and impact of analytics. Two research communities -- Educational Data Mining (EDM) and Learning Analytics and Knowledge (LAK) have developed separately to address this need. This paper argues for increased and formal communication and collaboration between these communities in order to share research, methods, and tools for data mining and analysis in the service of developing both LAK and EDM fields.
Short Title: Learning Analytics and Educational Data Mining
Notes:
Methods used in LA and EDM

What are they?

How are they used? examples?

compare and contrast the methods used

The methods used in LA seem to be more qualitative and more human oriented while in EDM the methods are more quantitative and statistical, that is, they focus on exploring the features of the data itself rather than trying to link the data with specific human beings.

pros and cons?

EDM is more factual, less complex than LA? (see complement)

what are the areas where these two overlap?

They both focus on the study of education data.

complementaries?In what ways and can LA and EDM cooperate with each other

If EDM is alone without LA, it seems it is an analysis without context. However, if it is LA without EDM, it seems like we are not able to isolate the effect of the individual and focus on observing the facts. EDM seems like the logical side while LA is incorporating the logic with more complex human behaviors.

insufficiencies even when applying both?

Look at the transition between the methods? What are the gaps? One of the difficulties is measure. How can the data be truly representative of the population? (measure, bias, non scientific, the immeasurable part)

Learning Analytics (LA) Methods

Social network analysis

- Dots and joint lines representing the relationship between humans

- Ways to monitor there similarities, interactions, influence, and etc.

- Used the concepts of graph theory

Sentiment analysis

- An analysis of sentiments expressed through language use

l  An example would be analyzing the positive and negative feelings expressed through social media.

influence analytics??

1. Analyze the influence of the data point in generating the pattern

discourse analysis

1. Analyze the language in written communication or debate to provide the trend.

learner success prediction

1. Through both quantitative and qualitative measures, predict the learning outcome.

concept analysis

1. Analyze the concept used in teaching , the fundamentals, to what extent can be understood by students and how do concepts build upon each other? The transition, interrelation, progression, combination, and application.

sensemaking models

1. In what ways do students make sense of the learning material? What, how, and how much do they understand? Why is it easier to make sense of something than the other?

Educational Data Mining (EDM) Methods

Classification

1. Classification method identifies the character of data points and allows for categorization (can be supervised or unsupervised)

*mapping an unlabeled instance to a discrete class by a classifier [categorical]

regression (a type of classification) mapping from an unlabeled instance to a value with a continuous range

example: identify a student as having a math test score of 70 based on online assignment performance

[continuous, numerical: assignment of value]

 

Clustering

1. The clustering method allows us to group data with similar features together for further observation. Multiple levels of relationship can exist between any two data points, for example, the relationship can be single direction, mutual, or just existing.

* a type of unsupervised learning

 

 

Bayesian modeling

1. Not sure, a method related to probability distribution?

relationship mining

1. Method to find out the relationship between data points and allows the automation to predict the relationship between the observed points and any additional data.

discovery with models

1. Use different models to fit and analyze data to discover the behavior of the data

visualization

1. Use graphics to illustrate the data and facilitate the understanding of underlying statistics.
Automatic Tags: Collaboration; educational data mining; learning analytics and knowledge

Author: Zheng, Alice
Title: Evaluating Machine Learning Models
Abstract Note: Data science today is a lot like the Wild West: there’s endless opportunity and excitement, but also a lot of chaos and confusion. If you’re new to data science and applied machine learning, evaluating a machine-learning model can seem pretty overwhelming...
Notes:
p7-18 talks about evaluations of classification metrics, ranking metrics, and regression metrics as well as cautions in training and evaluating metrics and skewed data sets. The gist of each section is as following.

Classification Metrics

Classification is about predicting class labels given input data.

Accuracy

the ratio between the number of correct predictions and the total number of predictions (the number of data points in   the test set)

Confusion Matrix

One might want to look at how many examples failed for class 0 versus class 1, because the cost of misclassification might differ for the two classes, or one might have a lot more test data of one class than the other.

Per-Class Accuracy

When the classes are imbalanced, i.e., there are a lot more examples of one class than the other, then the accuracy will give a very distorted picture, because the class with more examples will dominate the statistic.

few examples of one class, then test statistics for that class will have a large variance, which means that its accuracy estimate is not as reliable as other classes.

Log-Loss

if the raw output of the classifier is a numeric probability instead of a class label of 0 or 1, then log-loss can be used.

Log-loss is a “soft” measurement of accuracy that incorporates this idea of probabilistic confidence.

related to what’s known as the relative entropy, or Kullback–Leibler divergence.

AUC

The ROC curve shows the sensitivity of the classifier by plotting the rate of true positives to the rate of false positives.

how many correct positive classifications can be gained as you allow for more and more false positives

Ranking Metrics

Precision-Recall

Precision answers the question, “Out of the items that the ranker/classifier predicted to be relevant, how many are truly rele‐ vant?” Whereas, recall answers the question, “Out of all the items that are truly relevant, how many are found by the ranker/classifier?”

Precision-Recall Curve and the F1 Score

By plotting precision versus recall over a range of k values, we get the precision-recall curve. This is closely related to the ROC curve.

One way of combining these two numbers is via their harmonic mean:

F1 = 2* precision*recall / (precision + recall)

Unlike the arithmetic mean, the harmonic mean tends toward the smaller of the two elements. Hence the F1 score will be small if either precision or recall is small.

NDCG

DCG and NDCG are important metrics in information retrieval and in any application where the positioning of the returned items is important.

NDCG stands for normalized discounted cumulative gain. There are three closely related metrics here: cumulative gain (CG), discounted cumulative gain (DCG), and finally, normalized discounted cumulative gain. Cumulative gain sums up the relevance of the top k items. Discoun‐ ted cumulative gain discounts items that are further down the list. Normalized discounted cumulative gain, true to its name, is a nor‐ malized version of discounted cumulative gain. It divides the DCG by the perfect DCG score, so that the normalized score always lies between 0.0 and 1.0.

Regression Metrics

RMSE

This is defined as the square root of the average squared distance between the actual score and the predicted score.

Euclidean distance between the vector of the true scores and the vector of the predicted scores, averaged by n, where n is the number of data points.

* sensitive to large outliers

Quantiles of Errors

robust estimators of performance that aren’t affected by large outliers, such as: median absolute percentage:

MAPE = median (|(yi – yi )/ yi|)

It gives us a relative measure of the typical error.

“Almost Correct” Predictions

Perhaps the easiest metric to interpret is the percent of estimates that differ from the true value by no more than X%. The choice of X depends on the nature of the problem.

 

Caution: The Difference Between Training Metrics and Evaluation Metrics

Sometimes, the model training procedure may use a different metric (also known as a loss function) than the evaluation. This can happen when we are reappropriating a model for a different task than it was designed for.

It is always better to train the model to directly optimize for the metric it will be evaluated on.

 

Caution: Skewed Datasets—Imbalanced Classes, Outliers, and Rare Data

If class imbalance is not properly dealt with, the resulting model may not know how to pre‐ dict the rare classes at all.

Large outliers can cause problems for a regressor.

Effective solutions for large outliers would probably involve careful data cleaning, and perhaps reformulating the task so that it’s not sensitive to large outliers.

Author: Leong, B; Polonetsky, J
Title: Why Opting Out of Student Data Collection Isn’t the Solution

So it should come as no surprise that the “when” and “how” of parent and student opt-outs of education data collection or use has become a robust

Author: Educause
Title: Why Is Measuring Learning So Difficult?
Abstract Note: Several higher education learning and assessment professionals discuss the difficulties of measuring learning.
Notes:
I like the idea that analytics should not just be a diagnosis of what is happening now, but what else is possible. Since learning is dynamic and multidimensional, assessment should be an ongoing process that evaluate growth over time and promote further development, rather than a conclusion of what happened to the test and assign a fixed label to the learner.


Moreover, measuring learning is difficult because the measurements are usually oversimplifications, such that we may throw away the signal and keep the noise. Moreover, the definition of learning concerns many aspects and can be composed of multiple levels, such as memorizing, understanding, applying, relating to another subject, communicating to another person. No simple test can encompass them all.


The video also reminds me of the idea of customization. I understand that people’s decisions are shaped by their various backgrounds, personalities, and social context, but the business companies do not simply say, “Oh, it is so difficult to meet every individual’s needs because people are complex.” Rather, they provide opportunities for people to customize their goods, collect data about customers’ interests and send advertisement materials accordingly. I think being aware of the complexity and challenge of something is the first step; the next is to collect data, design methods to respond to the question.
Automatic Tags: Assessment; Education; educational assessment; EDUCAUSE; Higher Education; learners; Learning; Teaching and learning

Author: Weinersmith, Zach
Title: Saturday Morning Breakfast Cereal
Notes: The comic is fun. In a few images, it shows the deep connection between data finding and analysis with education, media, politics and society. It is interesting how little are students and teachers involved during the whole process, even though they are the ones mostly affected by the education reform. This comic makes me to raise and think about some questions such as, what kind of data should we collect, how authentic and representative are these data, what analysis should we come up with, how should that analysis be applied into the educational context, who should be involved during the decision making process, and who does these data, analysis, and reform serve?

Author: Clow, Doug
Title: Data wranglers: human interpreters to help close the feedback loop
Publication Title: Proceedings of the Fourth International Conference on Learning Analytics And Knowledge
Notes:
The complexity and quantity of data asks for meaningful sense making and the build up of a community environment for learning analytics. Developing the competence to use and interpret data should be a concern on an individual as well as institutional level. Experts such as data wranglers need to guide the process and help others in the learning community to better analyze and make use of data. Not only students and teachers should be aware of the value of data, but also managers and policy makers: The former generate data and make changes at the frontline while the latter can take action on a greater scale and see the bigger picture.

  • Context: large student body that requires centralization and many administrative systems and processes – could lead to a gap between learning data and academics who need to analyze and use the data
  • Data Wranglers: data interpreter who analyze data and propose helpful and effective recommendations for teaching practice. They collect data, analyze them, make charts and visualizations. They also collaborate with faculties to make sure that their analysis centers on key points. They listen to feedback and provide further assistance if needed. In addition to data analysis, they help users to get familiar with learning analytics and promote a community that adapts this approach. In the end, they help others to understand and use learning analytics more directly and efficiently (curriculum design, learning activities, discussions). Move the focus away from the subject being taught to how it can best be learned by students.
  • Parts that need improvement: data quality/ more data (historical data for comparison, updated data connected to institutional structure and system)/ capacity of data wranglers and the quality of their interaction with faculty members/ timing of reports and course selection

Author: Kucirkova, Natalia; FitzGerald, Elizabeth
Title: Zuckerberg is ploughing billions into 'personalised learning' – why?
Abstract Note: Zuckerburg wants to plough billions into personalised learning, but his way may not be the right way.
Notes:
• The article focuses on three ideas: 1) the benefits and danger of personalized learning 2) The balance of using technology to assist learning 3) Zuckerberg’s business mindset in supporting a particular type of personalized learning. I need more information to make a judgment on Zuckerberg’s motive, intention, and success in this domain in particular. My personal opinion on the relationship of technology and education is that teaching and learning is not only about content learning, but also human interactions and development. Technology can be used to help this learning, interaction, and development, but not to substitute it. In addition, changes that can impact education and human development need transparency and time.
  •  Regarding personalized learning, the authors suggest that only giving the information that learner interested in does not suite the purpose of a well-rounded education. I think having personalized learning to meet one’s interests and needs does not mean that one has no opportunity to expand their interests. Students can still focus on what they are interested in and good at while exploring others subjects. In short, people do not need to be terrified in seeing the word, personalized. As the authors themselves stated, personalized learning that involves student inquiry, teacher assessment, school requirement can be effective. To personalize is a complex process that requires ongoing assessment and evaluation of learning. In fact, personalized learning is to respond to students’ individuality, dynamic and context based learning.

Author: Georgia Tech
Title: Feature Selection

Author: Hanneman, R.A.; Riddle, M.
Title: Chapter 1: Social Network Data
Notes:
Though social network data can be treated as a special type of conventional rectangular data array, it can be seen in a different way that promotes diversity in statistical application. Two major emphasis in network analysis are: 1. seeing how actors are located or "embedded" in the overall network 2. seeing how the whole pattern of individual choices gives rise to more holistic patterns. The major difference between conventional and network data is that conventional data focuses on actors and attributes; network data focus on actors and relations.

The sampling of social network data is most likely dependent since the selection of each data point can influence the other through the ways they are connected and therefore include all the points within a boundary. But sampling in a larger population ( or a level above) could be independent, that is to obtain data from several populations and compare them. Network analysis can also have multiple levels, or modalities, that is to see how the relation between larger groups are built through the connections between individuals within the groups.

Different scales of measurement are also introduced. In sum, the binary measures of relations are most frequently used due to its simplicity.

Binary measures of relations
Multiple-category nominal measures of relations
Grouped ordinal measures of relations
Full-rank ordinal measures of relations
Interval measures of relations

It would be interesting to see the combination of behavior detector and network analysis to predict the influence of behavior within a network, i.e. is certain behavior "contagious" in a certain kind of network?

Author: san Pedro, Maria Ofelia; Baker, Ryan; Bowers, Alex; Heffernan, Neil
Title: Predicting college enrollment from student interaction with an intelligent tutoring system in middle school
Notes:
• Students start to think about college and academic achievement from middle school. Their performance, engagement, and disengagement during this period can predict their future enrollment at school.
  • Past indicators such as financial resources, family backgrounds, career aspirations are not enough. In addition, previous indicators such as attendance issue, violence, and failing grades are quite late for intervention. Figuring out new indicator: We can use data generated by students’ use of educational software to make a prediction. In this case, the accuracy is 68.6% correct.
  • Not to assess them after their study, but during their study (interaction with educational software), will save teachers more time. The information will also be more precise and accurate, without personal bias.
  • Questions about the ASSISTment system:

1) Then there is only one way to answer the question, what about other solutions?

2) The multi-level hint is great, but what about students who will just click on without thinking, because they know that they will eventually see the answer?

  • Model Features:

1) Student Knowledge Features

  • BKT: 4 parameters – Lo, T, G, S

* Question: Does answering the questions mean students have the skill? What if the question is not well designed, or if the students have help along the way?

2) Student Affect

  • Boredom, engaged concentration, confusion

3) Student Disengaged Behaviors

  • Off-task, gaming the system, carelessness
  • Conclusions: Affect and disengagement (boredom and gaming with educational software) at the level of middle school can be a factor of lower college enrollment./ high performance and academic achievement (accuracy in answering math questions) is a positive indicator of college readiness./ educational software can provide immediate and effective interventions to address the problems. *It seems that the ASSISTment system is only for mathematics, is one subject alone sufficient enough to predict college attendance? What are the other factors?

Author: Greller, Wolfgang; Drachsler, Hendrik
Title: Translating Learning into Numbers: A Generic Framework for Learning Analytics
Abstract Note: ABSTRACT With the increase in available educational data, it is expected that Learning Analytics will become a powerful means to inform and support learners, teachers and their institutions in better understanding and predicting personal learning needs and performance. However, the processes and requirements behind the beneficial application of Learning and Knowledge Analytics as well as the consequences for learning and teaching are still far from being understood. In this paper, we explore the key dimensions of Learning Analytics (LA), the critical problem zones, and some potential dangers to the beneficial exploitation of educational data. We propose and discuss a generic design framework that can act as a useful guide for setting up Learning Analytics services in support of educational practice and learner guidance, in quality assurance, curriculum development, and in improving teacher effectiveness and efficiency. Furthermore, the presented article intends to inform about soft barriers and limitations of Learning Analytics. We identify the required skills and competences that make meaningful use of Learning Analytics data possible to overcome gaps in interpretation literacy among educational stakeholders. We also discuss privacy and ethical issues and suggest ways in which these issues can be addressed through policy guidelines and best practice examples.
Notes:
• Background Information
  1. Data and information retrieval technology – personalized learning (How does personalized learning reduce delivery costs and increase collaboration between learners?)
  2. Data economy made data collection easier and more affordable than questionnaires or interviews/ behaviors of the entire constituency VS sampling/data collected from people in a natural context (not questionnaires when people know they are being analyzed), authentic and reflect uninterrupted user behavior. (How about data about people who do not use electronic devices, underdeveloped countries) observational data gathering VS intrusive collection (But how could behaviors on a service level reveal people’s inner motives and thoughts, and worlds beyond their digital usage? For example, a person who loves Canada Goose suddenly moved to Florida?)
  3. Educational datasets (evaluation, learner feedback and support, early warning system, learning technology, and future learning applications) learner oriented.
  • 6 Key Dimensions-Soft (humans or society in general, ethic, openness of data) and hard (technical and theoretical questions) – internal limitations, external constraints, stakeholders, objectives, data, and instruments.

 

Reflection from Objectives: self-evaluation based on self-data as well as on others’ data (teacher to student, school official to teacher) *avoid institutionalization goes over personalization

Want to learn more about “Machine learning Techniques” that allow learner profiles to be built automatically without leaners filling in and maintaining profile data. Interesting.

  • Traditional model (government, institution, teachers, students) and other models: peer evaluations, serious games (team collaboration) – can lead to dependency and legal constraints. Can be non-formal or informal
  • Support individual learning process & organizational knowledge management

 

  • Problem Zones
  • Potential dangers

1)          Quantitative VS qualitative: the reasons and motive behind performance and behaviors

2)          Prediction: judgments about a person can be limited and harmful because people change and their learning styles and abilities evolve. Their strengths also lie in different aspects of learning./prejudices (race, social class gender, etc.)

3)          Certain technologies are not pedagogically neutral, and can thus influence the analytics process.

  • Barriers and limitations of LA: Diversity and complexity of learning and earning profile
  • Framework as a guide for setting up LA services to support (educational practice, learner guidance, quality assurance, curriculum development, teacher effectiveness and efficiency)
  • Skills and competence required to interpret and act on LA results
  • Privacy, ethical issues, and ways to address them (policy guidelines and practice examples) data ownership and openness, ethical use and dangers of abuse

Discussion

Easily accessible data through automated collection of uninterrupted user behaviours is a great complement to data collected through surveys and questionaires. A comparison of the true and perceived behavior. (non intrusive)

By identifying and engaging the isolated students, we are able to have more input in the discussion.

The ownership of data generated by a person is complicated. Only with consent, the data can be used by another entity. However, there may be disparity between the perceived and true extent.

Author: Kay, Judy; Maisonneuve, Nicolas; Yacef, Kalina; Reimann, Peter
Title: The Big Five and Visualisations of Team Work Activity
Abstract Note: We have created a set of novel visualisations of group activity: they mirror activity of individuals and their interactions, based upon readily available authentic data. We evaluated these visualisations in the context of a semester long software development project course. We give a theoretical analysis of the design of our visualizations using the framework from the “Big 5” theory of team work as well as a qualitative study of the visualisations and the students’ reflective reports. We conclude that these visualisations provide a powerful and valuable mirroring role with potential, when well used, to help groups learn to improve their effectiveness.
Notes:
• I like the idea that “task work does not equal to teamwork.” Indeed, putting learners into a group does not automatically make them a functional and effective team. The authors created visualizations of the group work of a software development course. They tied the visualizations with the “Big Five” teamwork theory, examined the relationship of the graphics and theory, as well as students’ reflections. The visualizations provided long term, high level, and graphic summary of individual activity within teams (details VS whole picture).
  • Interestingly, the report does not aim to provide guidance because the authors acknowledged that structure and effectiveness of teamwork is affected by the context and how well the group members know each other. Therefore, interpretations are left to the team members or those who know the contexts. In addition, leaving decisions to groups members to promote more autonomy and motivation.
  • The “Big Five” components of teamwork:

1)  Team Leadership

2)  Mutual performance monitoring - able to understand team environment and monitor teammate performance

3)  Backup behavior - understand others’ needs and responsibilities including balance workload among members

4)  Adaptability - able to adjust strategies based on chancing conditions and information

5)  Team orientation - value and respect other individual while believe in the importance of team goal (versus individual goal)

  • § Visualizations
    • Ø Activity Radar: circle - range of participation/ colored dots - a team member or a classroom or a group/ moves to the center - participation increases/ a person whose dot is in the center has the highest level of participation whilst a person whose dot is on the perimeter has the lowest level of participation/ darker purple circle perimeter -the average level of participation. Medium – SVN, Wiki, Ticket.
    • Ø Interaction Network: node - a user/ an edge represents an interaction between the two corresponding users. /The width of the edge - number of interactions between them.
    • Ø Wattle Tree. The tree starts - the user first performs an action in any of the three media considered/ The left axis - day number/ Wiki-yellow “flowers”, SVN- orange flowers, size of the flower – contribution size, Tickets- leaves, a dark green (left) leaf indicates opened ticket while a light green (right) leaf indicates a closed ticket.
Automatic Tags: Artificial Intelligence (incl. Robotics); Computers and Education; Information Systems Applications (incl. Internet); Multimedia Information Systems; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction

Author: Konstan, Joseph A.; Walker, J. D.; Brooks, D. Christopher; Brown, Keith; Ekstrand, Michael D.
Title: Teaching Recommender Systems at Large Scale: Evaluation and Lessons Learned from a Hybrid MOOC
Short Title: Teaching Recommender Systems at Large Scale
Notes:
• Exploration of MOOCs (see how it affects university education, department visibility and reputation, as well as understand the procedure, technology, and methods) at the gradate level – gather data for research. Examine the differences between students enrolled in the concepts track and programming track in their learning of Recommender Systems.
  • Evaluation: surveys of demographics, self-assessed skills, learning intent, learning experience, student process and outcome. Knowledge-assessment tool: before and after the course to measure learning, 5 months later to measure retention.
  • Overview of the course:
    • open to both public and university students/specifically designed software platform/accessible to nonprogrammers and programmers.
    • High attrition rate: total enrollment of 28, 389 VS 5, 643 students earned a nonzero final grade
    • Explore the impact of a MOOC: Who MOOC students are, why are they taking the course, what is success to them.
    • Participants: high level of prior experiences, working professional and graduate students who seek practical skills. *It seems that on campus students rate higher in terms of active participants, test taking, etc. 

 

  • Results and Discussion: effort expended in the course predicts knowledge gain. /concepts-only track with hand exercises achieved same level with programming track and added assignments (the latter gained additional programming knowledge though)/online-only students learned at least as much as face-to-face students. The former favored the pure convenience and learning pace thorough video watching./Intention predicts course completion./ Students benefited equally regardless of their background knowledge of the course subject./difficult to predict student end-of-term performance/ programming students retained more than concepts students. /increased public visibility and impact./benefit of multiple-choice exams

Author: Desmarais, Michel C.; Naceur, Rhouma
Title: A Matrix Factorization Method for Mapping Items to Skills and for Enhancing Expert-Based Q-Matrices
Abstract Note: Uncovering the right skills behind question items is a difficult task. It requires a thorough understanding of the subject matter and of the cognitive factors that determine student performance. The skills definition, and the mapping of item to skills, require the involvement of experts. We investigate means to assist experts for this task by using a data driven, matrix factorization approach. The two mappings of items to skills, the expert on one side and the matrix factorization on the other, are compared in terms of discrepancies, and in terms of their performance when used in a linear model of skills assessment and item outcome prediction. Visual analysis shows a relatively similar pattern between the expert and the factorized mappings, although differences arise. The prediction comparison shows the factorization approach performs slightly better than the original expert Q-matrix, giving supporting evidence to the belief that the factorization mapping is valid. Implications for the use of the factorization to design better item to skills mapping are discussed.
Automatic Tags: alternating least squares matrix factorization; Artificial Intelligence (incl. Robotics); Cognitive modeling; Computers and Education; Educational Technology; Information Systems Applications (incl. Internet); latent skills; Pedagogic Psychology; skills assessment; Student models; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction
Editor: Lane, H. Chad; Yacef, Kalina; Mostow, Jack; Pavlik, Philip

Author: Matsuda, Noboru; Furukawa, Tadanobu; Bier, Norman; Faloutsos, Christos
Title: Machine Beats Experts: Automatic Discovery of Skill Models for Data-Driven Online Course Refinement
Abstract Note: How can we automatically determine which skills must be mastered for the successful completion of an online course? Large-scale online courses (e.g., MOOCs) often contain a broad range of contents frequently intended to be a semester's worth of materials; this breadth often makes it difficult to articulate an accurate set of skills and knowledge (i.e., a skill model, or the QMatrix). We have developed an innovative method to discover skill models from the data of online courses. Our method assumes that online courses have a pre-defined skill map for which skills are associated with formative assessment items embedded throughout the online course. Our method carefully exploits correlations between various parts of student performance, as well as in the text of assessment items, to build a superior statistical model that even outperforms human experts. To evaluate our method, we compare our method with existing methods (LFA) and human engineered skill models on three Open Learning Initiative (OLI) courses at Carnegie Mellon University. The results show that (1) our method outperforms human-engineered skill models, (2) skill models discovered by our method are interpretable, and (3) our method is remarkably faster than existing methods. These results suggest that our method provides a significant contribution to the evidence-based, iterative refinement of online courses with a promising scalability. [For complete proceedings, see ED560503.]
Notes: The paper presents a method called eEPIPHANY to determine skills needed to master an online course. eEPIPHANY is a collection of data-mining techniques to automatically refine (or rebuild) a human-crafted set of skills, initially given by course designers and developer. eEPIPHANY has more flexibility than other methods such as LFA (Learning Factor Analysis) and matrix factorization methods (aka Q-matrix).The major goal is to provide constructive feedback to online course designers and developers for iterative course improvement. It turns out the method predicts more effectively than existing methods (LFA) and human engineered skill models on three Open Learning Initiative (OLI) courses at Carnegie Mellon University. Moreover, this method provides a significant contribution to the evidence-based, iterative refinement of online courses with a promising scalability.
Automatic Tags: Automation; Comparative Analysis; Correlation; data; Formative Evaluation; models; Online Courses; Skills

Author: Cortez, Paulo; Silva, Alice Maria Gonçalves
Title: Using data mining to predict secondary school student performance
Publication Title: Proceedings of 5th Annual Future Business Technology Conference
Abstract Note: Although the educational level of the Portuguese population has improved in the last decades, the statistics keep Portugal at Europe’s tail end due to its high student failure rates. In particular, lack of success in the core classes of Mathematics and the Portuguese language is extremely serious. On the other hand, the fields of Business Intelligence (BI)/Data Mining (DM), which aim at extracting high-level knowledge from raw data, offer interesting automated tools that can aid the education domain. The present work intends to approach student achievement in secondary education using BI/DM techniques. Recent real-world data (e.g. student grades, demographic, social and school related features) was collected by using school reports and questionnaires. The two core classes (i.e. Mathematics and Portuguese) were modeled under binary/five-level classification and regression tasks. Also, four DM models (i.e. Decision Trees, Random Forest, Neural Networks and Support Vector Machines) and three input selections (e.g. with and without previous grades) were tested. The results show that a good predictive accuracy can be achieved, provided that the first and/or second school period grades are available. Although student achievement is highly influenced by past evaluations, an explanatory analysis has shown that there are also other relevant features (e.g. number of absences, parent’s job and education, alcohol consumption). As a direct outcome of this research, more efficient student prediction tools can be be developed, improving the quality of education and enhancing school resource management.
Notes:
The paper expressed interest in knowing how to increase a student's dedication and performance. It focused on predicting student's performance base on demographic attributes and past school performance and attempted to identify the key variables. The information were obtained through mark reports and questionnaires. It turned out that past school grades have a much higher impact than demographic variables. This is interesting. What if we run demographic variables on past school grades?

There are three plans when the grades are not available - plan A: grades from recent years, plan B: grades from less recent years, plan C: grade values returned by regression. Plan A achieve the best result while plan C the worst. Although plan C does not achieve accuracy in prediction, it is a valid attempt in making up for missing data.

Five methods are used to compare prediction results - NV, NN, SVM, DT, and RF (need to look them up in detail).

Data Mining goals and methods:

DM goals (i.e. binary/5- level classification and regression) and four DM meth- ods, i.e. Decision Trees (DT), Random Forests (RF), Neural Networks (NN) and Support Vector Machines (SVM),

Important demographic variables:

number of absences, reason to choose school, extra educational school support), demographic (e.g. student’s age, parent’s job and education) and social (e.g. going out with friends, alcohol consumption

Author: Baker, Ryan S. J. d; Corbett, Albert T.; Roll, Ido; Koedinger, Kenneth R.
Title: Developing a generalizable detector of when students game the system
Abstract Note: Some students, when working in interactive learning environments, attempt to “game the system”, attempting to succeed in the environment by exploiting properties of the system rather than by learning the material and trying to use that knowledge to answer correctly. In this paper, we present a system that can accurately detect whether a student is gaming the system, within a Cognitive Tutor mathematics curricula. Our detector also distinguishes between two distinct types of gaming which are associated with different learning outcomes. We explore this detector’s generalizability, and find that it transfers successfully to both new students and new tutor lessons.
Notes:
This paper presents a detecting system that accurately determines whether a student is gaming the system instead of actively learning the knowledge. The system can distinguish two distinct types of students who gamed in the system with high and low post test scores. The paper focuses on the gaming behavior that results in bad learning outcome. The detector is powerful since it is transferable and can be applied to new student data and new lessons. However, the authors used caution when move on to developing interventions for trying to minimize consequences if the detectors were not accurate, in other words, these are fail-soft interventions.

Behavior detection is a very exciting topic since the detector developed can be applied to a wide range of domains when a subject is gaming the system. For instance, the classic shirking versus not shirking behaviors of a manager in labor economics can be detected using a variation of this system.

Author: Martin, Rod A.; Puhlik-Doris, Patricia; Larsen, Gwen; Gray, Jeanette; Weir, Kelly
Title: Individual differences in uses of humor and their relation to psychological well-being: Development of the Humor Styles Questionnaire
Abstract Note: Describes the development and initial validation of the Humor Styles Questionnaire, which assesses four dimensions relating to individual differences in uses of humor. These are: relatively benign uses of humor to enhance the self (Self-enhancing) and to enhance one’s relationships with others (Affiliative), use of humor to enhance the self at the expense of others (Aggressive), and use of humor to enhance relationships at the expense of self (Self-defeating). Validation data indicate that the four scales differentially relate in predicted ways to peer ratings of humor styles and to measures of mood (cheerfulness, depression, anxiety, hostility), self-esteem, optimism, well-being, intimacy, and social support. They also relate to all five dimensions of the Five Factor Model and to Agency and Communion. The first two scales overlap with previous humor tests, whereas the Aggressive and Self-defeating humor scales largely tap different dimensions. Males scored higher than females on Aggressive and Self-defeating humor. It is expected that the HSQ will be useful for research on humor and psychological well-being by assessing forms of humor that may be deleterious to health as well as those that are beneficial.
Short Title: Individual differences in uses of humor and their relation to psychological well-being
